ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: learned techniques for the examination of condensed matters structure such as thermal analysis, mechanical properties, x-ray diffraction analysis, and microscopy
Learned how to write a scientific report based on materials testing I had done myself.

The theories and concepts in Materials Science and how they are used in real life to fabricate materials. Also, the tools and methods to analyze the composition of materials. We also learned how to write scientific papers as well as give presentations.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The schedule was kind of weird but it did allow plenty of time to write the report... mostly. The presentations at the end were all a bit haphazard because we received the news about who was doing what on short notice.

Overall a good course, but the workload was doubled this semester as students worked independently to write a formal lab report instead of in pairs. It felt a bit unfair to place this extra workload on students compared to previous semesters simply because there were less students taking the class.

I feel like this course could have been combined with MENG 286 class to create a 1.5 credit class, because back then when I was taking 286, the concepts did not really make sense because we did not see any demonstrations. In this class, we re-learn the concepts anyway so it's better to learn them just once and see how they actually work by combining the two classes.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not with Schroers, though if you have to take it, it's not the end of the world.

Overall yes, it is a fine course, not too large of a workload and you get to see the material science concepts you learn in MENG 285 applied to the laboratory setting. If you liked 285, I would definitely recommend this class.
